title: Writing a Text Editor - Computerphile
description:
Writing a text editor can't be that hard can it? Surely just a case of shifting around a bunch of ASCII characters? Dr Steve Bagley is based at the University of Nottingham 

Computerphile is supported by Jane Street. Learn more about them (and exciting career opportunities) at: https://jane-st.co/computerphile

This video was filmed and edited by Sean Riley.

Computerphile is a sister project to Brady Haran's Numberphile. More at https://www.bradyharanblog.com

comments.author: @tauraamui
comments.comment: Huh, weirdly opportune or relevant to what I work on most days these days. I am making a text editor which is basically Helix, but VIM motions are the first class citizen. It's called Lilly it's public on Github. He is absolutely right about the data structure stuff (the only part of the video I've seen thus far). I'm looking forward to watching the rest of this to kind of hear myself being spoken about indirectly from what the experience of making an editor is actually like. It's very fun, there's a huge range of difficulty of stuff to solve and implement, I really enjoy it.

comments.author: @dindu42
comments.comment: I wrote a text editor in Assembly language back in the early 80's and got it published on a magazine cover disk. It was a DOS app and was limited to a maximum file of 64k which was plenty back in the day. I didn't use arrays - I manipulated the text as one block of contiguous memory. Not suitable for scaling up but worked really quicky due to it being assembly language. It was called DGEDIT.

comments.author: @PetrSojnek
comments.comment: I was hoping you would tackle the worst problem in text editing: Editing file that is bigger than memory you have available. I was wondering what are efficient coping mechanisms (as you basically have to worry not only about writing/reading from memory but also writing/reading from file on disk which is monumentally slower).

comments.author: @thewelder3538
comments.comment:
This is *NOT* an efficient way of buffering input for a text editor, nor is it the method that is generally used.

The inefficiency comes from the fact that you need to move the data following the insertion point. What modern text editors actually do is to the insert into a separate buffer and then at convenient time, insert that buffer back into the insertion point. If the data is organised into blocks, it can be quite efficient.

comments.author: @jacobwerner8533
comments.comment: A while ago i wrote a line editor that was inefficient and not user friendly, but to edit the line, you had to retype the entire line. I think i had it where it had a menu to do different tasks and the user entered a number. The line would get copied into a buffer and thern rewrote back to the place it was. This video shows an efficient way to avoid a lot of problems i was having.

comments.author: @Lion_McLionhead
comments.comment: Remember early 8 bit word processors defaulting to overwrite because of that problem.  C64 speedscript used memmove.   A simple modern editor can normally call memmove for every keypress, which is so fast it's not noticeable.  The lion kingdom has continuously improved a text widget for 30 years.

comments.author: @kyrylmelekhin2667

Things get really interesting when you have to support bidirectional utf8 text, which may need to be rendered arbitrarily in reverse direction. Add multi width, syntax highlighting requirements to this and it becomes optimization nightmare.

I did this in Nextvi. Some say it's the best vi clone and certainly is for me.

comments.author: @timothy8428

comments.author: @chrisxdeboy
comments.comment: I wrote a simple little text editor in Nim. It worked much like the BASIC editors in most 80's computers, where you type the line number first, and it would strip off the leading number and space and put both in a tuple and insert that into a sequence, keeping the line numbers in order, and i eventually replaced the sequence with an AVL tree to keep insertion times near constant. Whole program was ~500 lines of Nim.

comments.author: @MissNorington
comments.comment: Visual Studio 2022 is the best text editor........ Super snappy and fast, especially with our slower CPUs we have today

comments.author: @magecu
comments.comment:
Wouldn't be better to allocate new "array" for each edit. Essentially each edit object would store at what position the edit start and a what position it ends and an array  the size of the edit. That would amount to a base array for the original text, a series of arrays holding the changes and an array holding all the starts and ends of the edit arrays. You could even use a single array and just append at the end of the array all the changes just with the change locations stored, but in this case you would need to store the index of the start in the text,  the index of the ends in the text, the length of the changed text and the index of the edited text.
As a bonus this approach would also work as a rudimentary undo and redo system.
Also once we save the file could use the arrays to only change portions of the file or insert sectors in between the file, lessening the load on the file system.
Am I missing something here?
After all this is just a back of the napkin idea for a text editor data structure.

comments.author: @akoskulcsar350
comments.comment: Please make a follow up video talking about more of the exciting solutions like the rope data structure.

comments.author: @klaxoncow
comments.comment:
"Append" strictly happens at the end - as there's "prepend" for adding at the start.

"Concatenate" means putting multiple things together. Order not being specified.

Not quite synonyms, but close enough that it doesn't matter.

comments.author: @elektronikvideos-bremen2873
comments.comment: Which editor was used to write first editor?😅

comments.author: @Ceelvain
comments.comment:
Each new place of insertion will cause the end of the file to be copied. A search&replace could really hurt if you're not clever about it (like storing the places to change the file and length of change on a first pass and then apply the changes in reverse order, from end to begin).
Wouldn't it be better to store the file in a balanced tree where leaves store a chunk of text? And a bad fragmentation could be avoided by enforcing a minimum chunk length (like 128 or whatever) when not actively inserting in it.

Now that I read wikipedia, it looks like I'm proposing a variant of the Rope data structure. ^^
Except i was more thinking of a (threaded) B-Tree rather than a binary tree. And with mutable variable-length smaller strings.
Makes a simpler and easier to manipulate tree. But recursive undo would require keeping an explicit copy of removed data.

comments.author: @custard131
comments.comment:
before you gave the answer of this gap buffer which was new to me, 
i was thinking
if you have a string struct which has a pointer to the first character, and a length
and then you store the text as a doubly linked list of these strings
when you first open the file, the entire file could be 1 string, or maybe you have some predefined logic for splitting them eg 1 per line
if someone wants to edit in the middle of a string, you split that string into 2 (doesnt actually require moving any of the underlying data around in memory, just updating pointers and lengths) 
then add another entry to the list which points to a newly allocated block of memory between those 2

this is based on my very simple understanding of how filesystems often handle writing files to disk, but i dont see why it wouldnt work in memory too

comments.author: @majorgnu
comments.comment:
Please make an effort to purge ASCII from your vocabulary as a substitute for plain text.

ASCII is a relic of the past and in our day and age it should only see use when necessary due to legacy and in the sense that 8-bit clean ASCII is a valid subset of UTF-8.
Otherwise, plain text should always be one of the standard encodings for Unicode.
At least in computers. Microcontrollers get a pass.

I guess that your video's purpose is to teach new tricks to people who program but probably did not study computer science at university.  Now how would this audience be able to remove the maximum line constraint ?  Thanks for a great video.  Your thinking is inspiring.

comments.author: @tomziller
comments.comment: You can come up with lots of ways to edit the middle of a line without doing a memcpy each character insertion or removal. But there is no avoiding the need to move all of the characters to the right of the cursor around on the screen as you insert or delete characters. And updating the screen is far more costly than updating your buffer. So any optimization of updates to your buffer are at best a micro optimization from the perspective of the entire operation.

comments.author: @okaro6595
comments.comment:
9:40 If you allocate the blocks with malloc it can add 16 bytes or so overhead as it stores things like the size of the block. Also 17 bytes would likely be rounded to 24 or 32 bytes.

Line wrapping actually is now standard in pure text files. In the era of 80 column displays it was common to end each line with a LF or CRLF depeding on the system. How with windowing systems the window on which the text is shown can be arbitrarily wide or narrow so it is not possible to format the text to the window width so it is better to let the editor wrap the lines and put a line break only at the end of the paragraph.

This of course doe snot apply to source codes where one should turn the word wrap off.

comments.author: @omgItsGreg
comments.comment:
Does that mean the gap has to move every time the cursor moves? Wouldn't that be quite inefficient,  since you have to move all text after the gap + add the gap?
 And what happens if the text the user write is longer than the gap length? Wouldn't it start overwriting text?
Also, how is the Delete key handled, where you have to delete text forward?

comments.author: @nosuchthing8
comments.comment: I remember a command called edline for dos. Edit one line at a time. Use that to code a full editor.

comments.author: @krishawkeye
comments.comment: For really large documents (papers / books / not so well structured source code), I would suggest adding a few gap buffers spread over the document.  An other addition could be splitting your document in blocks (pages / chapters / paragraphs, what works best).  Blocks could be stored in separate heap allocations; if a block needs to grow, the copy will be relatively cheap.  If blocks are not too large, you might not even need to copy around a lot, since you can insert blocks (heap allocations) at will, and use the left over space as the local gap buffer.

comments.author: @ArseniyPotapov
comments.comment: This is very interesting. Intuitively it feels like a linked list of smaller buffers is the best- minimal memory trade-off, great compute complexity. The author says the gap buffer is better, but doesn't show how.

comments.author: @chriswaine4101
comments.comment: When I started watching I wondered whether this was going to point out that part of why it might not be as easy as someone might hope is that features such as Unicode, undo/redo and clipboard support are expected.

comments.author: @ihrbekommtmeinenrichtigennamen
comments.comment: Another aspect of text editors is the user interface. I've seen too many terrible "simple text input boxes" where you can't move the caret with the arrow keys, you can't jump to the start/end with the home/end keys, you can't select text by dragging with the left mouse button or by hitting shift + arrow keys, you can't delete words with ctrl + backspace, you can't copy and paste with ctrl + c and ctrl + v, you can't select everythinig with ctrl + a, etc...

comments.author: @HikingUtah
comments.comment: This seems rather inefficient. If you had a file that was many megabytes long, you'd need to move megabytes of data when your insertion point moves.

comments.author: @BleachWizz

15:35 - another interesting thing to notice, if you really have controll of the memory is:
once you shifted the end of text is still there. if you imagine a copy of the text at the end and another one at the start you can notice that "moving the gap" is every time faster
supose you click before where you want to edit and then move further, it's possible that all you need to do is change the index too.
